what: How can I tell if my dataset is suitable for using this dashboard?
title: FAQ
text: lot longitudinal data least two descriptive columns (like types), match minimal needs starting dashboard. addition, data specific web-ID columns, MolPad make convenient createing links databases automatically.

what: How can I customize my dashboard?
title: FAQ
text: can edit title within gDashboard() function. additional personalization, adjusting colors sizes figures, can fork repository, create copy, make modifications dashboard.css file.

what: What should I do if I only have a few time points(<5)?
title: FAQ
text: Firstly, strongly recommend extending length longitudinal samples. can achieve increasing number measurements two days incorporating simulated data. options don’t suit needs, can also consider using “linear” method gNetwork() function.

title: Data Input

title: Data Input
text: Besides data type mentioned , methods allow three levels information: functional annotation, taxonomy annotation, feature annotation. matched ID columns annotation data, another input generating dashboard. support KeggID GOID automatic feature link generation, users set corresponding column name beforehand.

title: Navigating the Network
text: Navigating network MolPad dashboard follows three steps: Choose primary functional annotation adjust edge density tuning threshold value importance score. Nodes turnbright green (Fig 1.) represent clusters containing features chosen functional annotation. Brushing network reveals patterns taxonomic composition (Fig 1.B) typical trajectories (Fig 1.C). user also zoom specific taxonomic annotations filtering. View feature table (Fig 1.D) examine drop-options related function annotations, click link online information interested items. interface designed support iterative exploration, encouraging use several steps answer specific questions, like comparing pattern distribution two functions finding functionally important community members metabolizing feature interest. Fig 1: Dashboard Overview.

title: Navigating the Network
text: example discoversing related patterns network plot: Fig 2: Find related patterns network plot. ., two linked nodes dashed box closer inverse pattern . .b, groups less volatile average similar inverse patterns.

code: @Manual{,   title = {MolPad: MolPad: An R-Shiny Package for Cluster Co-Expression Analysis in Longitudinal Multi-Omics},   author = {Kaiyan Ma},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 1.0.0},   url = {https://kaiyanm.github.io/MolPad/}, }

what: MolPad: An R-Shiny Package for Cluster Co-Expression Analysis in Longitudinal Multi-Omics
title: MolPad: An R-Shiny Package for Cluster Co-Expression Analysis in Longitudinal Multi-Omics
MolPad: An R-Shiny Package for Cluster Co-Expression Analysis in Longitudinal Multi-Omics
text: MolPad offers visualization dashboard tool designed enhance understanding molecular co-expression works context microbiome data. approach involves using cluster network provide initial overview relationships across multiple omics, added functionality interactively zoom specific areas interest. facilitate analysis, ’ve developed focus-plus-context strategy seamlessly connects online curated annotations. dashboard comprises several components, including cluster-level network, bar plot illustrating taxonomic composition, line plot displaying data modalities, table pathway. can see illustration features screenshot.  Additionally, package simplifies entire pipeline creating dashboard. user-friendly design makes accessible even students limited R programming experience.

title: MolPad: An R-Shiny Package for Cluster Co-Expression Analysis in Longitudinal Multi-Omics
text: Clutering data k-means building group network. Find significant trend patterns datasets. Target interaction groups, taxons, pathways. Visualize distribution features specific pathways group network. Search particular features user-defined labels. Check detailed information feature automatically generated hyperlinks. better overall understanding datasets.

title: MolPad: An R-Shiny Package for Cluster Co-Expression Analysis in Longitudinal Multi-Omics
text: first input list datasets, normalized imputed. second input pathway dataset. Note datasets, first column must ID. information, please check corresponding functions.

title: Cheese data — cheese
text: study uncovered remarkably consistent microbial progression within cheese. bacterial community, Firmicutes dominate outset, Proteobacteria swiftly assuming dominance end ripening period. Additionally, Cheese Cheese C consistently demonstrate establishment Actinobacteria Bacteroidetes, distinct manner. corroborate findings using MolPad dashboard, conducted analysis two cheeses (C) three production batches, spanning weeks 2 13.

title: Generate shiny dashboard — gDashboard
text: outputs g-functions, ready create custom Molpad dashboard. sure specify web ID columns corresponding column names.

title: Generate shiny dashboard — gDashboard
code: gDashboard(   data,   cluster,   annotation,   networkres,   dashboardtitle = "MolPad Dashboard",   id_colname = NULL,   id_type = NULL )

title: Generate shiny dashboard — gDashboard
text: data dataframe; output pre_process() cluster list two; output gClusters() annotation dataframe; output gAnnotation() networkres dataframe; output gNetwork() dashboardtitle string. id_colname single string sting vector. column names annoation dataset contains external database IDs. id_type single string sting vector. corresponding database names columns, must choose "KEGG" "GO".

title: Generate shiny dashboard — gDashboard
text: Please ensure columns containing external database IDs adhere following standards: KEGG ID: Begin 'K' followed 5 digits, example, K05685 K06671. GO ID: Begin 'GO:' followed 7 digits, GO:0003674."

title: Generate prediction network — gNetwork
text: gNetwork() generates prediction network functional annotation. every feature, features considered independent variables, top predictors selected based %IncMSE.

title: Generate prediction network — gNetwork
text: clusters list two; output gClusters() ntop number. Pick top n predictors feature. seed number random seed.

title: Generate prediction network — gNetwork
text: assess relationships clusters using Mean Squared Error (MSE) changes resulting random shuffling. gNetwork()'s output includes edge weights node pairs, essential inputs dashboard.

title: Generate prediction network — gNetwork
code: data(test_data) networkres <- gNetwork(test_cluster, ntop = 3) head(networkres) #>      weight IncNodePurity var_names    from #> 1 2.6205607     0.6312900   Group_3 Group_1 #> 2 2.1131026     1.1182647   Group_5 Group_1 #> 3 0.1022914     0.6507438   Group_4 Group_1 #> 4 4.7239948     1.0502692   Group_4 Group_2 #> 5 4.3109750     0.8288986   Group_5 Group_2 #> 6 3.5211023     1.2343084   Group_1 Group_2 gNetwork_view(networkres) #> Warning: Removed 3 rows containing missing values (`geom_segment()`). #> Warning: Removed 3 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`).

title: Pre-processing datasets — pre_process
text: pre_process() function aids processing data inputs automatically establishes standardized format future use. allows two types data input: list datasets different sources long dataset containing specified column type. important note dataset, initial column designated IDs, subsequent columns expected contain values measured Time1, Time2, forth.

title: Pre-processing datasets — pre_process
code: pre_process(   data,   typenameList = NULL,   replaceNA = TRUE,   scale = TRUE,   autoColName = "Sec_" )

title: Pre-processing datasets — pre_process
text: data list datasets long dataset. typenameList vector dataset names. parameter applicable input format list. scale Logical; TRUE (default), scale datasets row. See also scale_by_row__ autoColName string; NULL (default), automatically set uniform column names datasets.parameter applicable input format list. replaceNa Logical; TRUE (default), replace NA 0.

title: Pre-processing datasets — pre_process
text: long dataset columns ID, Time1, Time2, ..., type.

title: Pre-processing datasets — pre_process
text: consider two distinct scenarios application: *one scenario, individuals collect several datasets various aspects instruments objects. example, might separately detecting lipids, metabolites, peptides specific soil sample. *scenario, data uniform quality, can categorized larger groups exhibit significant differences. cases, pre_process() function serves valuable versatile tool. Yet, function optional generating dashboard. Users can perform processing long format matches required output. However, mindful number samples (timepoints) must greater 5 avoid potential errors subsequent prediction section.

title: Scale by row — scale_by_row__
text: Scales values sample, row independently processed.

title: Scale by row — scale_by_row__
text: input expected data frame first column ID following columns containing observations different time points. ID column remains unaltered, columns double (dbl) format scaled.

title: Test data — test_data
text: synthetically generated dataset created basic testing purposes.

title: Test data — test_data
text: two datasets: data annotations

title: Test data — test_data
text: data frame 100 rows 12 variables: ID row ID T1~T10 count value 10 timepoints type type ~D

title: Test data — test_data
text: data frame 100 rows 5 variables: ID row ID GO_ID go ID KEGG_ID kegg ID system primary lable: 'Integumentary System', 'Skeletal System', 'Muscular System', 'Nervous System', 'Endocrine System', 'Cardiovascular System', 'Lymphatic System', 'Respiratory System', 'Digestive System', 'Urinary System' class secondary label: 'antibodies', 'contractile proteins', 'enzymes', 'hormonal proteins', 'structural proteins', 'storage proteins', 'transport proteins'

title: Transpose dataframe — transpose_dataframe__
text: function transposes provided data frame, using values first column new column names.

title: Transpose dataframe — transpose_dataframe__
text: expected input data frame first column serves Time, subsequent columns contain observations various features.

title: Transpose dataframe — transpose_dataframe__
code: a <- data.frame("Day"=c("Day1","Day2","Day3"),"feature_1" =c(1,2,3),"feature_2" =c(0,4,1),"feature_3" =c(1,1,0)) a #>    Day feature_1 feature_2 feature_3 #> 1 Day1         1         0         1 #> 2 Day2         2         4         1 #> 3 Day3         3         1         0 transpose_dataframe__(a) #>   Day1 Day2 Day3 #> 1    1    2    3 #> 2    0    4    1 #> 3    1    1    0
